Conclusions: The benefit of the OCT is the absence of direct contact with the cornea, and is a novel device to perform in vivo optical biopsies and promising research and clinical tool for the evaluation of corneal pathologic features in a non invasive manner, becoming an important equipment in clinical and surgical management of corneal diseases.ABSTRACT NO.: 55Comparative clinical study of the use of the cryopreserved aminiotic membrane and 360°conjuntival graft for the corneal ulceration treatment in dogs AL Andrade, GTNM Ferreira, TFB Souza, SS Sakamoto and TCC Silva Departament of Clinic, Surgery and Animal Reproduction, Ophthalmology Unit, Sao Paulo State University, Unesp, Araçatuba, SP, Brazil

back_matter.text: ABSTRACT NO.: 63 An invasive choroidal melanocytoma in a dog presented with behavioural changes BT Blacklock,* E Beltran,* RR Dubielzig, † D Donaldson* and C Hartley* *The Animal Health Trust, Centre for Small Animal Studies, Newmarket, Suffolk, UK; † Department of Pathobiological Sciences, University of Wisconsin-Madison, School of Veterinary Medicine, Madison, WI, USA Purpose: To report an interesting case of choroidal melanocytoma with behavioural changes. Methods: An 8-year-old neutered female German shepherd dog was referred to the neurology department at the Animal Health Trust for investigation of episodes of abnormal behaviour. A full neurological work up, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head and cerebrospinal fluid analysis, revealed no significant findings except for a lesion in the fundus of the right eye. The ophthalmology department was consulted and noted a raised, pigmented lesion dorsal to the optic nerve head. An ocular ultrasound revealed an 8 mm diameter homogeneous echogenic mass protruding into the vitreous from the retina/choroid and expanding caudally to follow the optic nerve for 3 mm. A presumptive diagnosis of an incidental choroidal melanocytoma was made. Thoracic radiography and abdominal ultrasonography to check for metastatic disease was normal. No visual deficit could be elicited. The lesion was monitored closely over the next three months, during which time the behavioural changes worsened and the mass increased in diameter to 12 mm. Exenteration was performed. Results: Histopathology confirmed a choroidal melanocytoma, excised with incomplete margins. Post-operatively, the owner reported a return to normal behaviour. Twelve months post surgery a repeat neurological work up was conducted due to an episode of staggering. The second MRI of the head showed no conclusive evidence of local tumour invasion or other pathology to explain the neurological signs. The dog lived for 27 months following initial diagnosis before euthanasia due to an unrelated condition. Conclusion: The possibility of the choroidal melanocytoma involving the optic nerve causing visual phenomena and subsequent fearful behaviour is discussed. Purpose: To evaluate a new technique for clinical treatment on pigmentary keratitis (PK) in dogs, using diamond burr superficial keratectomy (DBSK), medial canthoplasty and medical therapy. Additionally, assess postoperative complications and the control of the recurrence of the pigment. Methods: Two adult pugs with bilateral PK were included in this study. After undergoing general and ophthalmic examination, the patients were diagnosed with macropalpebral fissures and inferior medial eyelid entropion. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia adhering to the following procedure: correction of eyelid abnormalities by medial canthoplasty, and debridement of the corneal epithelium and superficial stroma using a handheld, battery-operated diamond burr with a 3 mm grit tip. Tobramicyn was injected subconjunctivally, and the eyes were stained with fluorescein to assess corneal damage. Postoperatively, both dogs were administered topical atropine twice a day, artificial tears containing vitamin B12 and tobramycin three times a day. Once the corneal ulcers healed, we began to apply Tacrolimus 0.02% twice a day. Results: The corneal epithelium healed without complications. Currently, there are a few remains of pigment, particularly on one of the patients' right eye, where the pigment was not completely removed with DBSK because it was deeper than on the other eyes. After one month, the pigment has not spread. Conclusions: DBSK associated with medial canthoplasty and immunosuppressive therapy is a promising method for the treatment of PK, and is a more economical and less aggressive procedure than traditional surgical techniques. Further evaluation of DBSK as a treatment for PK is indicated. To our knowledge, this is the first report of this practice.ABSTRACT NO.: 65 Central corneal squamous cell carcinoma in a cat: case report SE Borer-Germann,* C Watté,* K Gendron, † N Regenscheit ‡ and BM Spiess § *Ophthalmology Service, Vetsuisse Faculty, University of Berne, Berne, Switzerland; † Department of Clinical Veterinary Medicine, Clinical Radiology, Vetsuisse Faculty, University of Berne, Berne, Switzerland; ‡ Institute of Animal Pathology, Vetsuisse Faculty, University of Berne, Berne, Switzerland; § Ophthalmology Service, Vetsuisse Faculty, University of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland Purpose: To describe clinical presentation, diagnosis and treatment of an unusual corneal tumor in a cat. Methods: A 9-year-old European domestic shorthair cat was presented with a mass in the center of the left cornea, which had been progressively growing for 3 weeks. The cat had a longstanding history of unilateral keratitis. Ophthalmic examination revealed a 4 mm diameter, pink rounded mass with irregular surface in the central cornea. Further ophthalmic examination revealed no major abnormalities. Corneal cytology and biopsy indicated a squamous cell carcinoma. Pre-surgical tumor staging included thoracic radiographs, FNA of mandibular lymph nodes and cytology of the bulbar surface of the nicitating membrane. Ocular ultrasonography was performed to evaluate thickness and extent of the mass. Physical examination and routine blood screening were within normal limits. There was no indication of metastasis. The mass was removed by lamellar keratectomy followed by cryosurgery of the surgical bed. Postoperative treatment consisted in systemic anti-inflammatories and topical antibiotic and 0.04% mitomycin-c drops. Results: Histologic examination of the excised tissue confirmed the biopsy results and showed extension of neoplastic cells up to the deep side of the tissue. There has been no tumor recurrence for up to 1 year following surgery. Conclusions: Lamellar keratectomy with adjunctive cryotherapy and post-operative mitomycin-c drops was successful in treating a case of feline corneal squamous cell carcinoma even when surgical margins were not clean.ABSTRACT NO.: 66 Positive antibody titer for Encephalitozoon cuniculi in two cats with cataract in the Czech Republic R Stavinohová* and J Petrášová † *Clinic for diseases of dogs and cats, University of Veterinary and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Brno, Czech Republic; † Clinical Laboratory for Small Animals, University of Veterinary and Pharmaceutical Sciences, Brno, Czech Republic Purpose: We detected positive antibody titer for Encephalitozoon cuniculi in two cats with cataract in the Czech Republic (CZ). Methods: Fifty cats underwent ophthalmological and clinical examination at the University in Brno in 2011. We determined five neutered male cats (six eyes) with a median age of 4.4 years to have cataract. One cat had unilateral mature cataract with mass in anterior chamber and another one had unilateral anterior cortical cataract following blunt eye trauma. Because of no obvious cause of cataract, three remaining cats underwent complete blood work, serum biochemistry, indirect immunofluorescence (IgM, IgG) for Encephalitozoon cuniculi (EC) and Toxoplasma gondii (TG), SNAP Ò FIV/FeLV test, ELISA analyzes or immunochromatography for Chlamydiaceae. Results: All three cats were negative for FIV, FeLV and Chlamydiaceae as well. First cat had unilateral anterior cortical cataract, bilateral superficial keratitis, corneal erosion and conjunctivitis and had plasmocellular pododermatitis, was positive to EC (IgM 1:40, IgG 1:80) and to TG (IgM-negative, IgG 1:320). Other one had bilateral anterior cortical cataract, superficial keratitis, corneal erosion and conjunctivitis, was sneezing, coughing and was negative to EC and TG. Third cat had unilateral anterior and posterior cortical cataract, unilateral uveitis and bilateral conjunctivitis, was sneezing, coughing, lethargic and was positive to EC (IgM 1:40, IgG-negative) and negative to TG. Conclusion: This is the first evidence of Encephalitozoon cuniculi in cats in CZ. We suggest screening of seroprevalence of EC in cats in CZ. We consider this to be important due to the zoonotic risk of EC to immunocompromised humans. Purpose: To describe an orbital pseudotumor in a German Shepherd. Methods: A 12-yearold, intact female German Shepherd was presented for apathy and chronic inflammation of the left eye (OS). Ophthalmic examination showed exophthalmos, chemosis and an ulcerated medial periorbital mass OS. Intraocular pressure was 29 mmHg OS and 7 mmHg in the right eye (OD). Apart from the ocular findings, physical examination was unremarkable. Differential diagnosis for the ocular condition included: tumor, foreign body, severe orbital cellulitis, retrobulbar abscess, infectious granuloma (Leishmaniosis, fungal disease), pseudotumor and myositis. CBC and blood biochemistry showed neutrophilia and mild non-regenerative anemia. Abdominal ultrasound and thoracic radiographs were unremarkable. Fine needle aspiration of the mass was non-diagnostic and orbital MRI showed a high signal intensity medial mass (highest diameter 4.7 cm) with moderate contrast enhancement and associated to exotropia OS. Biopsy of the ulcerated periorbital mass was performed. Results: Histopathology showed an extended fibrosis with a multifocal and severe pyogranulomatous inflammatory infiltration. Leishmania spp., Mycobacteria and fungi were ruled out (IPI, Ziehl-Neelsen and PAS). Systemic corticosteroids (0.5 mg/kg twice daily) and azithromycin (10 mg/kg once daily) were started, as well as topical symptomatic medication. After 2 weeks, the mass involved the nasolacrimal system, there was marked epiphora, facial palsy, lagophthalmia and exophthalmia OS. A new MRI confirmed the diffuse orbital invasion. A mass biopsy was obtained by orbitectomy and a conjunctival buccostomy was performed OS. Histopathologic findings were consistent with the previous ones. Based on the diagnosis of orbital pseudotumor, systemic azathioprine was added to the systemic steroids. In 1 month, the orbital inflammation decreased and completely disappeared by 3 months. Until now, the patient has been under systemic treatment for 9 months, with no clinical signs of tumor regrowth. Conclusions: This is the first description of an orbital pseudotumor in a dog. Although pathogenic mechanism could not be established, the canine pseudotumor could be less malignant than the feline. Like in human, the canine orbital pseudotumor can be successfully treated with systemic corticosteroids and immunosupresors.

The use of air-dried amniotic memebrane for the treatment of canine complicated and uncomplicated corneal perforation A Trbolova, M Holickova and Z Kovacova Clinic of Small Animals, University of Veterinary Medicine and Pharmacy, Kosice, SlovakiaPurpose: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the efficiency of using an ADAM for the surgical repair of corneal perforations in four dogs. Methods: Three dogs (breed Springer spaniel, German Shepherd and Pug), 6-11 years of age were presented with corneal perforating ulcer. One dog, breed German Shepherd, aged 5 was presented with traumatic corneal perforation. The amniotic membrane harvested from cesarean mare section was sterilized in peracetic acid solution. The drying process was performed in laminar flow cabinet. Rehydrated amniotic membrane was sutured to healthy tissue with simple interrupted pattern of 9/0 non-absorbable material (Ethicon). Postoperative treatment consisted of systemic and topical antibiotics (3 weeks), systemic anti-inflamatory drugs (2 weeks), and topical mydriatics. All dogs were reevaluated 2, 4, and 8 weeks after surgery. Results: The successful use of the air-dried amniotic membrane resolved the corneal perforations in both complicated and un-complicated cases. The epithelization occurred within 8 weeks. The presence of vascularization occurred in all patients from libus to periphery of AM, except in case of traumatic perforation. Pigmentation around the AM was observed in one case.
